content: The "Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007" excludes discharges of indebtedness on a principal residence from gross income. The Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007 excludes qualified principal residence indebtedness discharged before January 1, 2010 from gross income. The Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007 excludes qualified principal residence indebtedness discharged before January 1, 2010 from gross income. Special rules apply to reduce the basis of the taxpayer's principal residence. The Mortgage Forgiveness Debt Relief Act of 2007 excludes qualified principal residence indebtedness from gross income. The excluded amount reduces the basis of the taxpayer's principal residence. Qualified principal residence indebtedness is defined as acquisition indebtedness with certain limits. The term 'qualified principal residence indebtedness' refers to acquisition indebtedness with limits, excluding certain discharges not related to the taxpayer's financial condition. The discharge of a loan may not be subject to certain tax provisions if it is due to services performed for the lender or other factors unrelated to the taxpayer's financial situation. If only a portion of a loan is qualified principal residence indebtedness, the tax provision applies only to the amount discharged exceeding the non-qualified portion of the loan. The tax provision applies to the amount of a loan discharged that exceeds the non-qualified portion, based on the taxpayer's financial condition. The tax provision applies to the amount of a loan discharged that exceeds the non-qualified portion, based on the taxpayer's financial condition. The term 'principal residence' has the same meaning as when used in section 121. Coordination amendments are made to section 108(a)(2) and 108(a) of the Code. The tax provision regarding loan discharges is amended to include a new subparagraph (E) and a provision stating that the principal residence exclusion takes precedence over the insolvency exclusion unless elected otherwise. These amendments apply to discharges of indebtedness on or after January 1, 2007. SEC. 3 extends the treatment of mortgage insurance premiums as interest until December 31, 2010. The effective date for this amendment is after December 31, 2007. SEC. 4 introduces alternative tests for qualifying as a cooperative housing corporation. SEC. 4 introduces alternative tests for qualifying as a cooperative housing corporation, including requirements related to gross income and property usage. The alternative tests for qualifying as a cooperative housing corporation include requirements for gross income, property usage, and expenditures. The amendment applies to cooperative housing corporations where property is used for residential purposes by tenant-stockholders, with 90% or more of expenditures benefiting the tenant-stockholders. Effective for taxable years ending after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 5. EXCLUSION FROM INCOME FOR BENEFITS PROVIDED TO VOLUNTEER FIREFIGHTERS AND EMERGENCY MEDICAL RESPONDERS. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 adds a new section, SEC. 139B, which excludes benefits provided to volunteer firefighters and emergency medical responders from gross income. In the case of qualified volunteer emergency response organization members, gross income excludes qualified State and local tax benefits and qualified payments. Deductions and expenses related to their services are subject to specific rules to prevent double benefits. The deduction for qualified volunteer emergency response organization members is determined considering any qualified State and local tax benefit. Expenses related to their services are deductible only if they exceed the amount of any qualified payment excluded from gross income. The term 'qualified state and local tax benefit' refers to reductions or rebates of specific taxes provided by a State for services as a member of a volunteer emergency response organization. A 'qualified payment' is any payment provided, excluding reimbursements, that exceeds the amount excluded from gross income. The term 'qualified payment' refers to any payment provided by a State or political division for services as a member of a volunteer emergency response organization, not exceeding $30 per month. The term 'qualified volunteer emergency response organization' refers to a volunteer organization that provides firefighting or emergency medical services for individuals. The maximum amount a taxpayer can receive for performing services in such an organization is $30 per month. The term 'qualified volunteer emergency response organization' refers to a volunteer organization providing firefighting or emergency medical services in a state or political subdivision. This section does not apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2010. The term 'qualified volunteer emergency response organization' refers to a volunteer organization providing firefighting or emergency medical services in a state or political subdivision. This section does not apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2010. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007. Subclause (I) of section 42(i)(3)(D)(ii) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended regarding student housing eligible for low-income housing credit. SEC. 6 clarifies that single parents and their children can qualify for low-income housing credit if they are not dependents of another individual. The amendment in section 7 applies to housing credit amounts allocated and buildings placed in service before or after the enactment date. It also addresses the joint return limitation for capital gains exclusion on post-marriage sales of principal residences by surviving spouses. The amendment allows surviving spouses to exclude up to $500,000 from capital gains on property sales within 2 years of their spouse's death. The amendment allows surviving spouses to exclude up to $500,000 from capital gains on property sales within 2 years of their spouse's death, effective for sales or exchanges after December 31, 2007. SEC. 8. Modification of penalty for failure to file partnership returns; limitation on disclosure. Extension of Time Limitation for filing partnership returns is increased from 5 months to 12 months. Penalty amount for failure to file partnership returns is raised from $50 to $85. Limitation on disclosure of taxpayer returns to certain individuals is also amended. The amendment limits disclosure of taxpayer returns to partners, S corporation shareholders, trust beneficiaries, and estate beneficiaries by excluding certain taxpayer identity information from supporting schedules, attachments, or lists. The amendment restricts the disclosure of taxpayer identity information in supporting schedules, attachments, or lists related to partnership, S corporation, trust, or estate returns. The effective date for this amendment is the date of the enactment of the Act. The disclosure of taxpayer identity information in supporting schedules, attachments, or lists related to partnership, S corporation, trust, or estate returns is restricted. The effective date for this restriction is the date of the enactment of the Act. SEC. 9. PENALTY FOR FAILURE TO FILE S CORPORATION RETURNS. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a penalty for failure to file S corporation returns under section 6699. Penalty for failure to file S corporation returns under section 6037 includes a penalty determined under subsection (b) for each month of non-compliance, not to exceed 12 months, unless due to reasonable cause. Penalty for failure to file S corporation returns under section 6037 is determined under subsection (b) at $85 multiplied by the number of shareholders, not to exceed 12 months, unless due to reasonable cause. The penalty for failure to file S corporation returns is assessed against the S corporation at $85 per shareholder, not exceeding 12 months, unless due to reasonable cause. Deficiency procedures do not apply for the assessment or collection of this penalty. The penalty for failure to file S corporation returns is assessed at $85 per shareholder, not exceeding 12 months, unless due to reasonable cause. Deficiency procedures do not apply for the assessment or collection of this penalty. The penalty for failure to file S corporation returns is $85 per shareholder for up to 12 months, unless due to reasonable cause. The amendments in the section apply to returns after the enactment date. The percentage for corporate estimated taxes is increased by 1.50 percentage points. The percentage under subparagraph (B) of section 401(1) of the Tax Increase Prevention and Reconciliation Act of 2005 is increased by 1.50 percentage points.
